docs.abstract: City Room blog: Sean Basinski, lawyer and director of Vendor Project at Urban Justice Center, answers readers' questions; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: According to the new Congressional Budget Office analysis, the Senate Finance Committee's health care legislation would cost $829 billion to provide insurance coverage to millions of Americans. But over 10 years, it would also reduce federal deficits by $81 billion. Huh?
docs.abstract: Analysis by Congressional Budget Office of Senate Finance Committee's health care legislation shows that savings generated by slowing Medicare growth, combined with revenues from new taxes, will more than cover cost of providing health benefits to 29 million people; health care economists say reducing Medicare costs would not adversely impact patients' quality of care (M)
docs.snippet: According to the new Congressional Budget Office analysis, the Senate Finance Committee's health care legislation would cost $829 billion to provide insurance coverage to millions of Americans. But over 10 years, it would also reduce federal deficits...

docs.lead_paragraph: News on Wednesday that the Congressional Budget Office had issued its cost analysis of the Senate Finance Committee's health legislation prompted dozens of reader comments. Here is a sampling, in some cases condensed from longer postings: I am glad the report came out and had the cost analysis. Now, we can move forward with the legislation. I believe the Sen. Majority Reid will put together a stronger bill, possibly (hopefully) with an employer mandate, along with an individual mandate maybe, and go forward. Although I am hopeful that a public option will be included, I think Reid may let the option come to the floor to be voted on. I believe this time we will get health care reform finally in the U.S. It may not be what I want all at once, but will set the ground work for a better one later.
docs.abstract: Readers' comments posted on nytimes.com in response to cost analysis issued by Congressional Budget Office of Senate Finance Committee's health care legislation (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In response to nearly 60,000 uninsured city residents, San Francisco started a health care program in 2007 called Healthy San Francisco. Anne Underwood, a contributor to the Prescriptions blog, discussed the program's results so far with William Dow, a health economics professor at the University of California, Berkeley. Here is an excerpt of the longer conversation posted on the blog:
docs.abstract: Excerpts of conversation with William Dow, health economics professor at University of California, Berkeley, posted on Prescriptions blog; Dow discusses San Francisco's health care program; photo (M)
